thread.title: Things to Do in Alabama: Oct. 16-18, 2015
thread.title_full: Things to Do in Alabama: Oct. 16-18, 2015

author: Ben Flanagan | bflanagan@al.com
title: Things to Do in Alabama: Oct. 16-18, 2015
text:
Press-Register file photo/Mike Kittrell 'Woodlawn' in theaters now 
The made-in-Birmingham movie "Woodlawn" opens in theaters nationwide on Oct. 16, but you can catch a glimpse of the film in a new trailer released by the film production company. 
Much of the movie takes places in Birmingham in 1973, when a spiritual movement swept through Woodlawn High School, uniting the school and the football team and inspiring its star player, running back Tony Nathan. 
"Woodlawn" also depicts the historic 1974 Banks-Woodlawn football game , at which an estimated 42,000 fans crowded into Legion Field to not only see a clash between two of the city's football powerhouses but also two of the most celebrated high-school players in Birmingham's history â€“ Woodlawn's Nathan and Banks quarterback Jeff Rutledge, who later became teammates at the University of Alabama. 
The movie was shot on locations in and around Birmingham last fall, and the filmmakers spent several nights filming at Legion Field . -- Bob Carlton (Photo courtesy of Pure Flix and Provident Films) Holiday Market in Montgomery 
Friday and Saturday, Oct. 16-17 The Multiplex at Cramton Bowl, 220 Hall Street, Montgomery Tickets: $10 Enjoy shopping until 9 p.m. on Friday, with a fun evening of dancing, drinks and special discounts with the purchase of a $10 Girls Night Out Discount Card. Shopping lasts from 9 a.m. until 5 p.m. on Saturday, when kids can have photos taken with Santa Claus from 9 until 3. Learn more. Junior League of Montgomery Boo at the Zoo in Birmingham 
Oct. 16-18 Birmingham Zoo, 2630 Cahaba Road, Birmingham Watch the Zoo transform into a destination of spooky attractions for Boo at the Zoo presented by Wells Fargo. Enjoy the Skeleton Skate Ice where families can skate with friends on the all new ice rink. Also be sure to check out the Trails of Africa. Dress in costume to take a ride on the Haunted Hay Ride, while also trying a spin on the Scarousel and trick-or-treating your way through the Zoo and more. Tickets cost $6 for members, $8 for non-members. Individual ride tickets cost $3.50, while unlimited ride wristbands cost $15.
